reviewText:
I'm a big fan of driving games, whether it be GRID, Forza, Gran Turismo... you name it I've played it.

Test Drive Unlimited 2 got a lot of bad ratings from companies, but they never understood what it was made for. It wasn't designed for racing, yeah it had a racing storyline on the side, but coming from TDU1, it was all about driving around a beautiful island with your friends calmly and enjoying the scenery.

So if you are looking for a game where you drive to 3 million miles an hour crashing at every corner, go play need for speed. But if you're looking for that one game you actually enjoy doing nothing but driving around on... this is for you.

Most underated driving game of all time.
If I had to choose my most favorite driving game... this would be No. 1.

ps. dont be fooled by the small amount of hours I have on steam, I have over 500 on my xbox.

reviewText:
As my car hurtles over the tallest cliff in Hawaii, I take one last look in the rear-view mirror. How did it come to this? For the longest time I was just another loser, content with a mundane life and those brief moments of escapism. Somehow over the course of nearly 30 hours in Test Drive Unlimited 2, I became a monster.

Sometimes when people play videogames, it's to get away, like a virtual vacation. But there are those times, where I don't want to be a plumber, a rodent with an attitude, a criminal, or Laura Bailey. I just want to drive around in expensive automobiles. In the real world I own two cars, one of them has a busted alternator. The other? No brakes. Despite being unable to start or stop, I've maintained the same driving job for the past decade. I'm always driving through the same neighborhoods meeting the same people every moment of every day. On top of all that, if Florida is considered America's ♥♥♥♥, then I live in one of its hemorrhoids. But hey, all I need is an hour or two a day of wonderfully escapist adventures and I'm golden.

I was a fan of Test Drive Unlimited 1 on the Xbox 360. The handling wasn't particularly good, but the atmosphere and sense of exploration was excellent. With a few fixes, better graphics, and more content, it could be my ideal driving game. I'm not sure what I was expecting with the sequel. I read all of the reviews, noted that there are major problems such as Securom, dysfunctional servers, and so on. I considered the possibility that this game might not even work. But I gave it a shot anyway...

...I'm at a party...alright..cool I guess. Apparently I'm a woman now. It's just like Skyrim except I'm wearing clothes and I don't think I have a six-foot-long p-.
PepsimanVsJoe! Enjoying your birthday party?"
Oh It's my birthday? I had no idea. Apparently I'm a silent-protagonist so all I can do is smile.

No way! This is one of those end-game vehicles. I must be dreaming. This is so totally meta.

Sure enough the real game begins

reviewText:
A terribly flawed game. Graphics were dated, even upon release. The car handling is vague and unresponsive, even on hardcore mode. The story is awful. The character models and voice acting is even worse. The car list is diverse if you enjoy European cars, but terribly lacking for Japanese and American models. Buying cars can be a grinding task of repetition. Buying houses is worse. There are countless glitches. Online support ceased years ago.

However, even will all it's flaws, I this is still one of my favorite games. The expansive roads of Ibiza AND Oahu are amazing. 2 massive islands that will takes you countless hours to explore. The maps are really the key gameplay elements. Once you adjust to the vague controls, there is a true sense of speed when cruising through the mountains, or beaches, or canyons, or through the city. Though games like Forza Horizon do offer a better overall experiance. TDU2 offers true driving freedom.

Even with the dated graphics, this game can be truely beautiful. With all the houses and cars on offer, this will give an avid car fan who needs to collect everything hours upon hours of fun.

Ignore the garbage story, accept the dated graphics, adapt to the steering ambiguity, and you have one of the most fun sandbox driving games available.

reviewText:
Great game, game honestly gets boring after time but it keeps you occupied that is for sure
Ok what’s included in this review: Servers, Windows 10 Support!

Servers; those of you who say the Servers are down:
1. Check server status and the store News page in case there are any issues.
No issues?
- If you can find 0 issues then it is more than likely the ports are being blocked somewhere, it’s actually really easy to tell if the ports are being blocked! The launcher tells you this! If the ports are blocked the text above the loader bar will be in red; if it is in RED then please search up on Google on how to open TDU2 ports (Skill Level: Moderate), this should take you no longer than 10 minutes to do this TIP: try portforarding.com they have a really handy tool that helps you get started.
If you know the ports are open inside your router, it’s time you checked your firewalls! If you have windows firewall (as rubbish as it is) you need to allow the application access to the internet usually automatically prompts you to do this on first launch, secondly you need to free up the TDU’s ports as well.
Ok when you launch the game the launcher will come up, if you still see the RED text then don’t worry it’s just a minor bug; all you need to do is close the launcher and re-open the game (this may take a few attempts) you are looking for GREEN text, if you have tried at least 10 times:
Firstly restart your Router and your PC then revert to the above ^^ statement.

Windows 10:
Windows 10 at first load up appears that it does not support the game; It pops up with the readme.htm file telling you that the game is not supported, however there is a way around this! First of all close the game.
-- Those of you who do not know what Troubleshooting compatibility is, search up for some helpful tips on Google! :) –
- Yes you guessed it! You are going to be using Compatibility to get the game working, note: you only need to do this once!
Firstly: goto your game library, locate TDU2, right click the game and select Properties, goto the Local files tab, click Browse local files
Secondly: Locate these 2 files: TestDrive2.exe and UpLauncher.exe. Right-click each one separately, click on “Troubleshoot Compatibility”, click “Troubleshoot program”, check “The program worked in earlier versions of Windows but won’t install or run now” -> click next, Select Windows 8 -> click Next, click “Test the program...” (needed to save the new settings) -> close the app after it opens -> Click next, click “Yes, save the settings for this program” -> Click “Close”. Repeat this for the other “EXE”, now you are done! Re-launch the game normally from steam and have fun!
Please rate my comment up if this helped you :)

reviewText:
Hello and welcome to my review of the relatively old game Test Drive Unlimited 2.
I am aware of the fact that the game was released in 2011, I've purchased it in 2013 and I will still review this title because the series are discontinued and I do still enjoy the game untill today.

Now something about me regarding the racing genre on PC.
I do not like racing games where you can race on a track, in a car which is almost unhandle-able ( in my opinion, ofcourse ).
With these games I mean Grid, and partially Dirt.

Okay, I did enjoy Dirt 3 and Dirt Showdown without a doubt but in the end, playing with a controller or a steering wheel, it didn't satisfy me enough to keep me playing these titles once in a week or more often.

So now back to what I do enjoy in a game of the racing genre.
I do really like the open-world idea, having a big map or several maps ( In Test Drive's case: Island ).
Driving around without anything forcing you do to anything, making speed and just drive all across the island on various landscapes with a nice sight does satisfiy me.

Buying a relaxing car, my Ferrari 458 Italia, Purple with black rims in this case: And just cruising around the island, on the roads with water to the right of me and the city to the left of me, hearing the engine doing it's work is what I like.

Not being forced to drive a track, do a race and aiming on finishing first without anything else you can do.
Just free-roaming in open worlds with customizable cars which you can upgrade and adjust to any specification you want.

And that's for the driving part, now for the experience in terms of sound.

The sound of the car, in various situations ( Driving in sand, dirt, or just a normal road ).
The sound is different every time, for every car in any situations ( weather too for example ) is just perfect in the game and these small things help me enjoy the game more than I already did.
Driving through a tunnel while It's raining in my custom white Nissan GT-R is what I can't do in any other game.
And these elements of Test Drive is what makes me want to play the game, the endless options to tune and adjust cars to exactly how I'd like to and then going on the road, hearing the right sound and feeling good when playing the game .. Yeah, that;

Now for the other part of the game:
Missions, Money, Houses and avatar.

Missions in Test Drive are tasks you have to complete which can be anything from getting a high adrenaline bar, but also could be driving above a certain speed and also opposite missions like driving really careful without the person next to you in the car getting sick.

These missions are pretty fun for the first few times but become boring quick, but they reward you with money to buy cars, houses and clothing.

Money in the game is pretty important ofcourse but I feel like you just have to keep grinding the repetitive missions to finally buy the car you have been wanting for a while.

So yeah, the method of money making within the game is something I don't like and that made me want to Cheatengine myself a couple houndred million instead of working for the money I want to buy the car I'd like.

Houses and Avatar: Besides the garage part to store your cars, I don't care about Houses or pimping your avatar ( Buying clothes, getting haircuts, etc ).

So yup, the car driving part is what I like the most of the game.

Okay, for some of you I might have not played the game in the right way, or not long enough but this was my final review of the game.

If I had to give the game a score from 0 to 100 I would give it a 85, some aspects could've been done way better ( Money making and missions ) but the driving itself is what makes the game a good open-world cruising game, and pretty unique in it's genre.
Okay okay, Grand Theft Auto is somewhat more bigger and to some also better but what I care about is the car driving.
In Grand Theft Auto the car driving is only fun when stunting and such with your friends.

So that's it for the review guys, I hope you have enjoyed reading my opinion about this game.

reviewText:
+ Quality of music selection was decent, and complemented the game's atmosphere
+ You can play around with your vehicles' accessories, such as deployable roofs, turn signals, and windows; not at all functional, but it is the little attention to detail that I appreciate
+ Fast travel is available for discovered points of interest, stripping away some of the monotony of driving from waypoint to waypoint
+ Healthy variation in biomes and terrain types
+ Absolutely massive traversible maps (Even better when you unlock Hawaii)
+ Reasonable variety of cars available in-game, and your choice of starter vehicles can actually remain viable alternatives for much of the early-mid game
+ Off-road tracks are some of the most fun in the game, and could be very creative in design and technical challenge
+ Funds are not too hard to come-by, reducing chances you will get bogged down and find yourself in a rut
+ Cars, character, and homes are shockingly customizable
+ Social aspects are both well-implemented and go a long way to improving potential replay value; being able to drive up to other players in real-time and challenge them to a race by flashing my headlights is a lot of fun, and I felt that it really added to the experience
+ Licenses are required to unlock different types of races and challenges; this expanded a feeling of progression

- Some of the requirements for leveling up are not adequately explained
- Despite the quality of many (not all) of the songs, the overall soundtrack is severely limited; there are only two available radio stations, and they cycle between, perhaps, 14 total tracks
- NPC drivers boast fairly awful AI, and prove far too easy to overcome
- Occasional, disappointing framerate stutters and other visual bugs that I had expected to be ironed out
- Invasive, time-consuming, unnecessary DRM; requires additional downloads and the creation of a third-party account (hosted on a poorly designed and barely function Web site, no less)
- Character animations, models, and voice-acting are rock-bottom abysmal
- Some game progress (such as requirements found under the 'social' category) requires getting large numbers of human-controlled players on your friends list and in-game, playing with you; simply put, however, this game doesn't appear to boast the player population to warrant this, and it will make these hurdles difficult to overcome

If you enjoyed this review, please follow my curator page. Also, feel free to join my group, LockeProposal's Big Day Out for discussion and announcements. Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
TDU2 has two very major and unsolvable problems:

1. The physics are just terrible. This is not even a matter for debate- check any review from when this was released. Regardless of of car class or cost, the cars handle poorly in general and have an unreasonable tendency to easily spin out of control even on dry roads.

2. Server Authentication. TDU2 has 'online' and 'offline' player profiles- think Diablo 2 with offline and Battle.net characters. These are completely separate saves and you cannot transfer progression from one to the other. The problem is, the Online Servers are constantly down for PC, meaning you cannot use your Online profile. Not only that, but around 25% of the game's content is only available with an Online profile. This is really a dealbreaker.

Behavior of npc opponents during races  created challenge. 3. A large selection of vechicles was available. 4. RPG features such as clothing/car appearence and preformance/housing/player alteration was abundant. 5. Basic driving fundamentals (driving schools) available and mandatory to advance.

Cons. 1. Layout* and NPC behavior. While driving around most" any curve while offroad at moderately high speed and you want to get sideways a bit? Rest assured that your entrance and exit of the curve has been carefully calculated and a tree has been placed at the exact center of your exit position and sometimes 2 to catch you just in case you swerve away from the first. Want to cut corners where you wish? No. You'll find carefully placed trees at most curves. Think you're clearing that tree? Nope. Suddenly you've rammed that tree head on exactly centered by your vechicle. You'll cut corners where you're allowed to and only in matches where they're obvious to the player. 2. NPC driving behavior.  While driving an 4 lane highway your forced to drive on the shoulder because as you approach 2 npc vechicles one will speed to tandem with the other closing an opening that you saw from a distance. Also say you're in an eight lane highway and want to open up the throttle? No. If any vechicle exists in the road ahead it will change lanes to be in yours.  Its 2 am in the middle of nowhere and you get a lead foot?  Vechicles will pop into existence before your very eyes in both lanes.
Approaching an intersection at high speed? cars will race to block sometimes intersecting and crashing while you're attempting to navigate. Driving through the mountains? And approaching a curve?  NPC vechicles will pop into existance race to the curve to beat you there then slow down to 20 mph entering the curve. You want to pass on a curve but dont want to use the shoulder? Consider that all curves are completely blind to you and that an NPC vechicle will pop into existance in the opposing lane as you pass. reviewText:
Well what makes me come back to this game time and again? Interesting story... no, great driving physics...no, interesting characters.. dont let me start on that, voice acting?.. you could say that if you were entertained by the repeating announcement that apparently the Wilder brother are squabbling with Stewart again (who-tf is Stewart I can only guess).

However this game has something. You have you car and the freedom to travel around two islands full of nice sights and sunny vistas. You can drive for hours, buy cars, houses or just explore at your leasure.  You can challenge other people whos worlds seamlesly intersect with yours like in Dark Souls. Or you can explore the world without invisible bounds around the roads, a bit like Skyrim in Cars. But even if you stop, the environment doesn't look as generic as for example in Need for Speed or Driver series, so you are really motivated to visit new places.

The graphics are great, there is a weather and day/night cycle. The views you get out of some of your Flats/Houses are amasing. The challenges a varied and exciting. There are also a pair of races around the Island, that can take nearly a real-world hour to complete. I mean if I think about it a bit more, this game is the opposite of what I really don't like about other racing games whith dumb driving on the same track over and over again with an extreme example being american Nascar where you just drive in a circle.

Sure the characters look like dorks and sound even worse, but then you see the attention do detail the developers put into the game and it's amazing.  Just try to explore the starting location. You will not see it any more after the first minute or so in-game but the effort put into it speaks for itself. If you take your time and look around at the nicely textured babes, whose breast actually bounce around a bit (in a racing game!), the bar with actually some bottles stuffed behind the counter, then you really get into this holiday Ibiza mood. Did I mention  I really appreciate that detail? There are also many cars each with detailed interior, which you can admire.
This game however is not without its (many) problems, to name a few:
- the characters are just plain silly and the story even more so
- you have to set the controls just so, or the driving experience will be awfull
- the driving physics could be much better (I miss dirt 2)
- there are no pedestrians (to drive over :)  ) anywhere!
- the developer is not in business any more
Well thats my 2c, you can get this game really cheap for less tha $10 on steamtrades, so if you just like to drive around, explore and do an occasional race, this is a game for you!

P.S. The Characters in this game are ridiculous and remind me of mega shark vs giant octopus movie. They either creep you out, like the same guy you pick at 2 am in car who is late for his meeting" or make you laugh hystericly because their dialogs dont correspond with the situation at hand.

Also I think this game in not effectively playable with a keyboard. There are some challenges
date: you have to complete for a Driving License with a ridiculously volatile car named Dodge Viper
recommended: where accelerating a bit too much or steering to far will make it spin uncontrollably."

reviewText:
It is a must buy!

Well after 150 hours this game is still fun and enjoyable. If you can get past the bugs, hackers and strange physics you too can enjoy this fantastic open world driving experience. The near GPS perfect mapped roads of Hawaii and Ibiza mean there is plenty of places to drive and explore. The variety of cars is not to bad either. I it is a real shame the studio who made this game went bankrupt but at least the online servers still for now, although that means there is no chance of getting an official patch for this game now. If the physics, graphics or selection of cars is not to your liking then you can easily mod it to suit your needs, just whatever you do play OFFLINE! I personally enjoy just driving about the place with friends or other who I meet in game so have chosen to remove the mods.

So if the price is too high for you liking then buy it in a sale, you won't be disappointed if you can look past the points I have mentioned.

reviewText:
One of the greatest driving games, that sadly you may never play. I have owned this game a little over 3 weeks and have made/met 18 of the coolest friends in that short time plus an absolute bucket load of friends using the retail version.
I'll cut to the bad news first. Firstly you have to make an account at http://www.testdriveunlimited2.com to be able to play this game and to buy DLC. Secondly, Eden games made this and unfortunately for what ever reson went belly-up. Atari luckily stepped in and took the game over but clearly they haven't got the server side stuff in control.
This means you get things like:
- Losing friends out of your profile and then sometimes they re-appear.
- You can buy DLC and then have them turn into mardi gras pink mustangs ( no joke they are vehicles won through a one on one duel with a campaign progress character).
-Some of the MMO aspects of the game fail or get broken regularly, meaning that you won't be able to find and join your buds or invite them to things like games in the casino or to your houses or for just a free-ride drive.
- If you want to get the casino and or drive a range of cars and bikes you have to buy Atari points at the TDU2 website which is a turn off for many people to say the least because it can be tedious although myself, I never had any issues with it.
The Casino DLC is $10AUD and cars work out to be $1AUD each @ $5AUD for 400 Atari points (Pay by Paypal for less hassle).
These things are the worst parts of the game and some come and go as mentioned.
Great things about the game:
- You drive in an open world and work your way through getting licenses for different classes of vehicles and events on the islands of Ibiza and Hawaii.
- Meet a lot of great people and make friends with people all over the world (personally I dont even have a problem with non english players) I just ask them, 'you use Steam? Add me as friend :)' even if they don't use the Steam version some make Steam accounts and add the game to non-Steam shortcuts. Then its easy, the add me and I have Google Translate open in the Steam in game browser so they can talk to me in their own language outside of in game chat, problem solved! :)
- Did I mention Bikes? :D
- Huge amount of Cars (some are DLC), unfortunately only 3 Bikes (DLC), huge array of clothing and customisations to your character by the use of plastic surgeon and to your cars by paintshops and tuning upgrades, a Casino and many properties that you can buy to house your vehicles. I totally dig the MMO aspect of this game even in it's breaks a lot state.
The game graphics may not look as good as say Grid2 but that never bothered me, I like the open world aspect and MMO of the game. I've bought almost all the DLC for the game too because I think the game is worth it especially when you snag it for $5 and there are ways to deal with stuff when the Atari/TDUlife servers break etc like the Steam adding to compensate as I mentioned. Also I should mention that my X-Box controller works very well for me in this game and the game does support a fair amount of G' series wheels but you might want to Google the game to find out for sure if it supports yours.
I dedicate this review to all the great people I have met in the game, they 'make' the game in my opinion. Also I'm going to put up some of the screenshots I have and will hopefully get the time to make a Youtube tribute to the game if not also my friends. It may be some time for TDU3 to come out and fingers crossed it will be for PC too. I won't wait around like I did getting this game I wished I'd bought it last Christmas.
One other thing. Don't or avoid buying DLC vehicles (Google TDU2 DLC vehicles list so you know which they are) you didn't pay for with Atari points when the servers get attacked/modified and become unlocked to buy with just cash. You need to have unlocked them with Atari points in game and or purchased at the TDU2 website because at some stage they will revert to pink Mustangs only worth around $25k. $1.5 million exotic car turning into a $25k pink Mustang....not cool and you'll just be throwing in game cash away.
Also, back your game save up periodically not that I've had any save game corruptions as of yet but there are many who claim they lost all they're game progress. The game saves literally everytime you go to the menu and when you quick travel so maybe that was fixed. Better to be safe than sorry I guess but to be honest I only started religiously backing them up when my Ducati that I legimately got with Atari points turned into a Mustang. Its not happened again with any other vehicle since and I did just rebuy it after selling the Mustang.

I love Driving Sims/Games, especially when I have a full racing setup with a Logitech G27 with the Stick Shifter, and a steering wheel mounted on an aluminum semi cage. reviewText:
This is the closest thing to Forza Horizon on PC... for better or worse. And trust me, the worse is pretty bad. But first, the better.

The game is spread across multiple hawaiian islands, in an open world campaign, which is pretty awesome. It also has a great selection of cars, missions, races and other things to participate in, such as painting your cars and altering your avatars appearance, clothing and hairstyle. So far, so good, the game really can be quite fun. I'd rate the physics as either one of the most realistic arcade games I've played, or one of the least realistic simcades I've played. But on to the negatives.

The game rarely works without modification, I had to use a standalone launcher (which takes away my ability to gain Steam achievements) to make the game work consistantly. Even still, I can only play a couple hours before the game crashes. But really... I'm ok with that. I'll tell you now what really, truly infuriates me.

There are certain timed missions in the game, that are absolutely, positively impossible to complete without driving like a balls to the wall, completely suicidal  lunatic. Take Mad Max style driving, and turn it up my 5. Then, add to that the fact that the most unpredictable traffic in the world is included, and the customer who's car you're delivering doesn't want it scratched, or driven off road, and welcome to the most utterly infuriating racing game ever known to man. I literally can't tell you the number of times that all I've needed to complete a mission is one more damn second, and everything would have been fine. But the game creators set time limits that apparently only God would be able to achieve, because not only must you be a driving god, you must also be the luckiest son of a ♥♥♥♥♥ in the world for traffic not to cut you of and screw up your entire damn race.

Now, I know the above paragraph is utterly critical, and even hateful of the game, but I still recommend it... especially on sale. I bought the game for $5, and I've gotten my moneys worth out of it already. I just really wish these particular missions were not made so freaking impossible. The other 95% of the game is fantastic, but that 5% of the games missions completely, and utterly infuriates me. Other than that (and the instability, and utter lack of reliable online support, and need to launch the game through a third party launcher) the game is pretty fun. Just be sure to pick up the universal launcher so you can play offline.

http://i-knyazev.ru/tools/tdu2-universal-launcher/

reviewText:
I bought TDU 2, as i felt i needed the feeling of driving a Lamborghini (or other nice cars) in exotic locations. Then i realized they left out the Lambos from the 2nd... I played a lot the first part and of course the driving physics are nothing to write home about, but there was a certain feeling to the free roaming going 300km/h in a cabrio Lamborghini or such cars in a huge island, and simply (and very sadly) there is no other game like this, that you can buy houses and nice cars in nice locations. So i didn't hesitate much when i purchased the second for like 20 euros or so. After investing 30 hours in it i realized the developers concentrated and tryed to improve on the wrong aspects of the first game to make this sequel. Which resulted in a worse game than the first.

The cop chases are downright broken. I like challenge, but the police cars coming straight at you with 200+km/h in a one direction road, and every few seconds. I think this is a major fault in this sequel. I remember the first TDU and there was nothing like this, the cop chases were fun and challanging in the same time. In a driving game this is important for me.

Also collecting points for making facial surgeries? Are you kidding me? I can get past this, as you can just ignore this feature, but this kind of mentality is visible throughout the game. Even if you dont want to, the game reminds you that you should be wanting to become the biggest ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of all time. The scenarios and missions could have been made very fluid and easy to believe, but they are just dragging you out of the environment and putting you into a minigame inside of a game.

Can't skip the cut scenes before the races, they are incredibly annoying after hearing them for the first few times.

Some cars have their gear rations mixed up. I realized in a few cars,i think they were Lotuses, that their 3rd gear is higher than their 4th. Basically these two gear ratios are swapped.

I understand they couldn't implement proper collision physics into the game with real life cars. But this is as far from test driving as possible nowadays. But at least the first TDU could somehow make me forget this. I was eager to get all the nice cars, and get some villas in nice locations. But the more i discovered and tryed out in the second part the more i got disillusioned. I just deleted it and i can not reccomend it to anyone, especially at this price. Maybe at a massive discount, but even then, you should stick with the first part in my opinion.

reviewText:
Good Start , Bad End
The game was released in 2011. I absolutley loved TDU1 ,so i decided to buy this one. At the start i was amazed.The Graphics , The Gameplay , The 2 Maps. Everything was great except my PC. Which could run the game with only 45 fps...
The game started its lifetime very well. It had alot of cars, Great multiplayer/online , casino , appartments , garrages and all the stuff that one good open world racing game needs. 1 Year after release they announced  The Bike DLC . I was so excited about it. It came out and it was good. The problem was , that u had to buy every bike individually. On that time the multiplayer was working , singleplayer was great and everything was done well for this game so far. But then the problems came.

Gameplay/AI
The Gameplay/AI had few problems:  Driving Licenses , Cops and Controlls.
Driving License: The problem is that some of the challenges , are too hard to complete or even impossible for some players. Without Driver License u cant progress through the higher rank races.
Cops: Just like the Driver License , here with the cops ... its too hard to outrun them. I like challenges , but for some players this is hell. They are always stoped by the cops , no matter what they do.
Controlls: For the players with wheels this is not a problem. But for players who use keyboard its really hard to drive. In TDU1 was better optimized to drive with keyboard.

Community
Just like the most of the games , they have good community base behind them. There was great  Mods  released by the community moders. It added more cars , skins and everything that one mod can add to the game. But then some Bad Modders" decided to ruin the fun for the most of the players. From this moment ...  The problems started

Late Multiplayer Problems and Site Problems/Closed Studio
However

reviewText:
Not sure why people say the server is dead its online for me chatted to a few randomers, I used some software called Portmapper (requires java) to portforward (make sure upnp is on for it to work)..

Pros:
While looking dated its still a beutiful looking game maps are nice (both islands)
Has the island from the original Test Drive Unlimited which you can go to when you advance far enough in the game.
Offroad vehicles (offroad has negatives though)
- Some nice cars like the ferrari california or koenigsegg
- Walking around in shops (its a nice touch even if the view controls dont work with the controller Wtf)
- Has some of the stuff that made the first one feel a bit special (opening windows, flashing lights, Radio)
- Has Indicators, (Sometimes i like to drive some what responsibly)
- Traffic is better compared to the first game, big improvement, no invisible police car bugs so far or just people randomly breaking in the middle of the road or driving down the road and turns his car into yours when you try avoiding).
- Truly Open World (not like a world with tons of invisible barriers and cant go up hills or what ever like far cry 4)
- The roads are fantastic in design some nice bendy roads, motorway/highways w/e plus tunnels
- Reason to explore, you can only go to said point if you have actually travelled there before, the fast travel option is nice for people who are trying to get money quickly for a nice car and some people may have limited game time hours)
- Runs great at 1080p maxed out with 8xAA on an old gtx480 :D (lowest drop ive seen so far is like 50fps its usually about 62-64fps)
- Works Fantastic with a logitech G25 wheel
- (not sure if pro but) Playing with a wheel is so immersive and really works well. You find yourself driving responsibly a lot of the time because its nice to do. You follow traffic, cruise around look at the nice scenary. Its bliss

Cons:
- Day Night is static and only changes to what ever that place is set to on the map. One place will always be night time   for example.
- No CLK DTM AMG? Why??? Where is the classics from the first game? Hardly any decent choice of japanese sports cars either its too european. The audi choice is not bad like there is a few but i want a nissan skyline or a silvia or rx7 those cars are more important than some silly hair dressors car like the 4x4 wannabe offroader that sucks at offroad
-Offroading only works with certain cars. I mean sure i expect some cars not to do as good but come on limiting the speed the way its done even though i should be going faster is annoying.
- Controls are a bit of a step backwards in some areas (controller using avatar mode and trying to turn does not work i have to use the pad and a mouse wtf)
- Radio Music mostly sucks. like 90% of the music on it and it gets too repetitive.
- Randomly crashing as soon as i load in to the server
- The atari account can be a bit of a ballache
- No test drive unlimited 3 so far.
- When I have somebody ring me up on a phone and i press cancel i dont want them to call back again a moment later its annoying.
- Some lack of car choices here and there. You just think pft really you could of had more of something else..
Quick thoughts.. Bought it on sale for a bit less than £4 It is a whole lot of game for that £4 I spent on it and worth every penny.. Sure it has a lot of flaws but its a nice game to get lost in and just immerse yourself into. I played The Crew and while a couple things about it might seem a bit better the game as a whole ain't got [s-h^i_t=] on test drive unlimited. Worth a buy. Its a game you will play for hours and feel like you only played five minutes of. I love how long it takes to get from one side of the map to the other also Kudos to atari for including a revamped updated version of the old map and NOT charging it as dlc. Devs hear this. We got the old map from the last game that has been updated and stuff, and a separate map on this game. We could of had tthe one map and it would of still been pretty much the same old but we got both without paying out our bummholes. Oh and there is a point to driving around that map too. The annoying thing about this game is the dlc cars using atari coins thing on the webpage.. Wtf even is that? Just put them in a pack put it on steam don't overcharge and make people happy I'm not going to the effort of atari coins ubisoft does a similar thing and they're as bad as ea.

Just buy it, be happy. The maps feel big, maybe not as big as the crew but the crew has like nothing to it and these maps are better.

reviewText: I've probably played this game more than I ever played any other. The graphics are a bit dated now and the driving is more arcade than anything meaning the cars handle and perform nothing like the real things or even similar representations in other games. The road design is often better suited to a Need for Speed franchise where wrecking is purposely added and part of the whole atmosphere of the game.\n\nSome of the stuff you do in the game, things required to advance and otherwise, seem pointless and like so what?" at best. Like clothes shopping and cosmetic surgery for a couple. Who really cares about either and most of the clothes are a joke and ridiculous beyond  belief. Many of the achievements needed to advance are very tedious and often require co-operation of other players. Good luck there both in finding enough players to help you and then finding enough good sports who'll actually help you. There's a casino DLC with its own blend of poker
recommended: roulette and some players seem to prefer the casino to driving. Advancing through the different level cars requires a tiered licensing before you can buy the faster cars.\n\nThe story is thin- you basically work your way through a racing series called Solar Crown using various class cars from old classics to high dollar exotics to off-road. You win cash and sometimes cars from AI drivers you compete against. Warning here- this is another game where the AI cars can bump you off the road
hoursPlayed: spin you out and all that while they are about totally resistant to anything you do to them. A wreck may cost you 10 or more seconds to recover from but the AI cars hardly slow down when they wreck.\n\nThere are 'missions' you do along the way to earn money and some of them are kind of dumb

reviewText: Starts out realy fun untill that fun starts to vapourize.  Seamless blending of multiplayer and single player is a bold claim made while in actual fact if the multiplayer servers are down you cannot play single player or anything.  The driving tests become impossible when you hit Hawaii mostly due to the vehicles supplied for the A class licence has the most terrible handling and will spin out of controll.  The vehicle upgrades improve performace of the said vehicle but offer not much in encouragement to upgrade.  You simply select from a list of leveled upgrades.  Often times you will find yourself googling for some answers as to how to do something as not everything is intuitive.  Driving around Ibiza or Hawaii you will often find what you think are challenges you can enter, which are infact multiplayer challenges that upon entering you soon find 0 online sessions, or ones you cannot join so in essence nobody seems to be hosting multiplayer challenges other than the instant challenges you can get from other players as you encounter them in the game.  The way to make money is to do the single player chalenges which there are plenty of but that hardly seems like a reason to have the multiplayer aspect in the first place.  And with the publisher layoffs how long with the servers be available.  Is it worth buying even if its on sale, no not realy.  Invest your money into something else.

reviewText:
(Before I start this review, I'd like to preface it by saying I STRONGLY recommend playing this game with a gamepad, and not a KBM. Otherwise, you're in for a very bad time)

IntroductionTDU2 is a very unique game. It's a driving game with heavy emphasis on social elements, such as real estate, clubs, clothing, and even (wait for it) hairstyles. That being said, I wouldn't see why anyone would want to play this offline, as most of the fun is found online. It was very buggy and otherwise a forgettable game at launch, but after numerous patches, both official and unofficial, I can certainly say that this game has had most of the kinks ironed out, and it's now a playable and fun game. TDU2 features more than 80 vehicles, miles and miles of drivable area, and several game modes for you to enjoy.

Content- 8/10This game features a little over 80 cars (more if you count mods, DLC, and prize cars), ranging from humble little cars like the Volkswagen Golf, to explosive hypercars such as the Bugatti Veyron. However, I will say something about the selection of cars in this game, and that is that I am very disappointed in the bias of cars. There are literally FIVE Pagani Zondas for you to choose from, 10 Ferraris, 4 Bugatti Veyrons, but not a single Honda, Mazda, or Toyota? Now that's just biased as hell. I would honestly rather be able to drive a preppy car like a Mazda RX7, Honda Civic, or Toyota Supra than I would some insane hypercar like the Ferrari 599XX, which almost guarantees that I'm going to crash it while going 250MPH, thanks to this game's ridiculous driving physics. The game does allow for you to explore more than 100 miles of in game area, spanning two islands, Hawaii and Ibiza, as well as several in game shops and points of interest. Still, I feel like the game would be a bit more enjoyable if the physics didn't make me so prone to crashing. Speaking of the physics, let's talk about them real quick.

Gameplay- 6/10Initially, I found the physics to be extremely jarring. The start of the game requires you to drive Tess, the game's main antagonist, to her photoshoot in her daddy's Ferrari. Every teenage boy's wet dream, right? Well, yeah, if I could actually drive the car without smashing it into every single corner. The cars in this game are able to accelerate very quickly, but holy hell, the braking and handling is just AWFUL. It literally felt like I was playing a 2011 version of Outrun, except I was in a much faster Ferrari, and the b!tch was yelling at me to slow the F down every 5 seconds. After finally making it to the photoshoot, my avatar" (who is literally the most metrosexual person I've ever seen

reviewText:
In this I both have postive and negative opinions, so read on if you wish so.

This game has a place in my heart. I got it in 2011 on the PS3 and it was fantastic. The feel of picking my character, driving my car and getting miffed off when I failed the licenses. This game will take some work to finish it, but you can download a save. If you are looking for a game, to drive around, just cruise innocently, this is for you. If you are worrying about graphics, I can run it on my AMD 7850K alone, with an avg. 62/63 fps on very low and an avg. 25/26 on very high.

However, since the bloody servers went down for good, the game just doens't have that same feel. It feels, dead, almost. Yes, you can cruise around, but you cannot meet anyone else and make a club, drive around with your friends, etc. The game doesn't have that same ring to it. I'm surprised the game is even still for sale, and at £14.99, I'd avoid it at that price. I got this in the sale for £3.74 I think. The game isn't even worth over £10 anymore. The developers have laid off the game entirely and abandoned it. To be honest, TDU3 would be nice seeing *wink*. The online servers aren't even up I don't think. I think the developers lost a battle in court or something, but I'm not sure.

Overall thoughts:

This is genuinley a fantastic game. The driving is a bit 'meh', but still driveable. The euphoria I sometimes experienced when driving on the coast in my Audi R8, was unreal. I have so much nostalgia for this. Back to my thoughts on this, TDU2 isn't worth paying £14.99 for. Get it in the sale, when it is considerably cheaper. Overall, I would recommend this game.

reviewText:
Test Drive Unlimited 2
I played just under ten hours of it on the night of February 28th into March 1st on the year 2015, straight through. The first hour and a half wasn't with out any difficulty as I had to fix a small issue with the launcher. It still doesn't work right, but I can open the game which is good enough for me. That ate up my first 15 minutes. Unfortunately I did not take that as a sign of things to come.

The next hour and fifteen minutes was spent trying to get the G27 to cooperate with my preferred settings. It wasn't until the end of that hour and fifteen that I realized that it was my fault that it wouldn't cooperate. Just one small issue, I wasn't clicking the right button to save my settings.

Once I got the controls sorted, the next 8 and a half hours was spent mostly cruising in my classic Mustang. The world is huge and open for you to explore, and there are two maps to explore. The driving could have been better polished, but it is still quite enjoyable. Additionally I find it nice to have the option to have Automatic, Sequential (Paddle shifting), H-Shifter or H-Shifter + Clutch options for driving. I drive the Mustang in Automatic mode as it has a 3 speed Auto. I prefer to keep things traditional in the game. If I drove a manual car, then I would be grabbing my own gears with the stick.

Finally towards the last two hours of it, I got a buddy of mine in this game and he and I cruised around. The multiplayer has to be the biggest flaw as it only works when it wants to. Other players can also be annoying as they constantly follow you and challenge you to unwanted races, but with the average population of 10 at the most, you can imagine why. If for some reason you're disconnected from the online play, how ever, you can still play and save your progress just fine. You would just be alone as all.

The game is nearly perfect if you want to go cruising around. It challenges your driving in multiple different ways with different style of driving with different types of cars. If you can get the multiplayer to work, you can go cruising with your friends. Or you can stick to single player and rack up Championships and Licenses to make more in-game money that can be used to cloth your avatar or trick out your ride, or even buy a house!

One last thing to mention is that the strongest of cars, the best lookers, you have to pay real-money for. Suggesting it has a pay to win model, but anyone can spend money on a nice car and not know how to drive it. In this scenario, it's all about perspectives.

Cons    Securom DRM is complete and utter ♥♥♥♥

reviewText:
When is a racing game not just a racing game? When it's Test Drive Unlimited 2. Not a sim and not an arcade racer, TDU2 falls somewhere in the middle, offering a massive open-world to explore with over 100 vehicles to do that with, from modest to exotic. For those who need to kick back, TDU2 offers many social features, and even a casino. With all of your hard-earned cash, you’ll be able to purchase new houses, vehicles, furniture, clothing and for some reason, even a haircut and plastic surgery.

The game's traditional race championships and missions alone can take 60+ hours to complete, but if you're a completionist like me, don't expect to put this down until you've amassed well over 100 hours. For all it delivers, TDU2 has proven to be one of my favorite racers ever.

I reviewed the game at Techgage: : http://techgage.com/article/test_drive_unlimited_2/

reviewText:
One of the best open-world racing game ? Definitely agree... How to introduce this game ? Easily. Imagine long highway with few cars, long and straight like a Route 66, then car of your choose... Pagani maybe, and that speed. Probably best description on this game.

More than 100 cars to drive, from Ferrari to Mercedes and Audi. From Jaguar to Alfa, and really, really more. And where they drop you ? Hawaii + Ibiza. Tropic islands full of long roads, beautiful places, and awesome views. Story is there just because somebody wants it there... It has no relevant point, only making of money, for buying cars and houses. You can style your character from eybrows to hairstyle, and of course your clothes. Houses are also ugly and luxury. You can own even a boat in which underwater garage you're able to put those beautiful machines...

The worst thing of all is, that multiplayer is dead. It's sad, but it's truth. At least we can be very HAPPY that Atari runs those servers at least for those few players that are in. I wonder when they turn off servers which won't be so far, and then multiplayer will be really dead. By this I want to say TD3.

In fact, I love this game. I love it more than any game of NFS series. I love it more than any Dirt or CMR... Any relevant rival would be The Crew from Ubi. But we'll see.

8.5/10 (Perfect)

reviewText:
A curiously empty experience now that the online elements are no longer supported. Lots of icons on the landscape that you will never get any value out of. You see bots around the place, probably designed to give the illusion of multiplayer activity during down times. Who knew they were racing against the machine back in the day? No way to tell.

The driving is OKish. The competitions are a bit one sided, at least to begin with. Either you win easily (90% of the time) or the AI does. There are no close finishes, effectively no actual racing. If you don't make a mistake you will most likely win. AI cars are glued to the track. No barging them off to gain places.

The game tries hard to be cool" but it's like a fifty year old dressing like a teen and getting it all wrong.

Shame."

reviewText:
This game is really poor.

The driving physics are the sort of thing you'd expect from a ps1 game. Other than looking at the speedo you can't really gauge or feel how fast you're going. You can't really drift on this game very well, which is stupid since it's something which you can use to earn money within the game. If you lose internet connection it will take you to the title screen and when you attempt to play again it will just make you watch loading screens without actually letting you play... it just takes you back to the title screen after a while because you have no connection (and carries on in a cycle). The online players as well as the pedestrian cars/bikes glitch a lot and jerk forwards like 200 yards up the road at times. I know it's not exactly a brand new game at this point, but the graphics really aren't anything worth shouting about.

If you have the sort of expectations of this game that I had, i.e. something which offers a good open-world driving experience similar to that of need for speed games, but with more realistic handling, better graphics and the sort of gameplay that wouldn't get boring quickly, you'll be entirely disappointed.

And also worth a mention is the pain in the ♥♥♥ installation...
AFter downloading via steam it not only makes you sign up to their website to create an account for the game (hardly the end of the world, I know, but there's more to come), you have to activate the game with a serial key (something I haven't had to do with any other steam game), when you try to launch the game it will make you download another gigabyte of data (probably files which make the game as crap as it is), which WILL fail to download... at which point you should refer to this:

http://support.atari.com/index.php?/Knowledgebase/Article/View/76/0/i-am-receiving-error-5

which should fix the problem for you, but in all honesty you'd be better not buying the game and saving yourself the hassle/disappointment

reviewText:
Pros:
Plays well
Handling is not arcadey but not simulator either
Looks good
Decent visual customization

Cons:
Repetitive as well as godawful radio station soundtracks where they tried to be like GTA with parody ads. Except they forgot the funny.
Grindy story with no variety
Servers are iffy at best. Hard to play with friends sometimes.
While the races are painfully easy (no challenge at all if you are even remotely decent), the liscense challenges (which are COMPLETELY UNNECCESSARY. I have NEVER used ANYTHING from the schools in the actual races) are painfully difficult and are really the only thing that will slow progress.
It's pretty much dead in the competitive scene. No Club VS Club, no multiplayer challenges, nothing. Hope you got some friends to boost with.

I say get it when it's on sale. I don't just play a game for 180+ for nothing.

Hardcore racers shouldnt buy this game and go back to gt5, NFS or whatever. But people who like beautiful cars, wonderful views and sims-mmo stuff will find it really interesting, like me.\nAlso, its like a racing mmo. In free-ride mode and in buildings you can see everyone who is playing game atm too and you can invite them to challenge or co-op driving/events. Or gather up your friends together and make party in your home, which you can customize too.

reviewText:
A continuum of a very open, unique, marvelous game Test drive unlimted. I started playing this series on the Playstation 2 and really loved how open and challeging it was. It's not like the other generic racing games where you just race a couple of times and instantly get a $1,000,000+ supercar. You have to work for hours upon hours in order to advance even a small percentage.

Even though I found it gets a bit harder in my opinion to earn money in Test drive unlimited 2 then the first one, I have found no annoying bugs, glitches or other major problems while playing it. The main things I think could be improved would be server downtime and NPC's (They act a bit awkward at times). The server downtime can get annoying on people who just started playing so that is why I recommend playing in offline mode first before you go out and show-off" your cars and items. If you don't know how to start in offline mode just ask me and I'll help.

Overall the game is very good

reviewText:
This game is really poor.

The driving physics are the sort of thing you'd expect from a ps1 game. Other than looking at the speedo you can't really gauge or feel how fast you're going. You can't really drift on this game very well, which is stupid since it's something which you can use to earn money within the game. If you lose internet connection it will take you to the title screen and when you attempt to play again it will just make you watch loading screens without actually letting you play... it just takes you back to the title screen after a while because you have no connection (and carries on in a cycle). The online players as well as the pedestrian cars/bikes glitch a lot and jerk forwards like 200 yards up the road at times. I know it's not exactly a brand new game at this point, but the graphics really aren't anything worth shouting about.

If you have the sort of expectations of this game that I had, i.e. something which offers a good open-world driving experience similar to that of need for speed games, but with more realistic handling, better graphics and the sort of gameplay that wouldn't get boring quickly, you'll be entirely disappointed.

And also worth a mention is the pain in the ♥♥♥ installation...
AFter downloading via steam it not only makes you sign up to their website to create an account for the game (hardly the end of the world, I know, but there's more to come), you have to activate the game with a serial key (something I haven't had to do with any other steam game), when you try to launch the game it will make you download another gigabyte of data (probably files which make the game as crap as it is), which WILL fail to download... at which point you should refer to this:

http://support.atari.com/index.php?/Knowledgebase/Article/View/76/0/i-am-receiving-error-5

which should fix the problem for you, but in all honesty you'd be better not buying the game and saving yourself the hassle/disappointment

reviewText:
I would say that this game is still the best open-world driving game out there. It is now a 4 year old game and yet no other game has reached the beauty degree of this one.

It has graphics good enough to compete with the recent games, it has realistic driving, it has an addicting customization system of vehicles. Unique sounds for all vehicles. It has a progress ladder you want to climb. It has two huge islands to explore. Hell you might not even want to race, but to chill on this beautifully designed tropical island. Just take your ride up the hill to watch the sunset and park it there. When the night comes, go down the hill and race some ♥♥♥♥. There is multiplayer, singleplayer, collectibles and rewards for those.

I have to admit that there is some weird sims ♥♥♥♥ going on in this game as well. Like you have to buy CLOTHES. And uh, HAIRCUTS. The game actually somewhat forces you to have plastic surgery as well. For the achievements anyway. I mean WTF? But seriously I don't pay any attention to that. I just focus on the beautiful part of the game. Another let down for me was the lack of old muscle cars. How can a game of this beauty not have those? Strange, but they at least have one or two of all time classics which almost makes up for it.

Anyway, for the record, kudos to the developers, and a shame for whoever shut them down (Eden Studios is closed now), but all in all this is the best open world racing-driving game there is right now. It was the best in its time, and it still is. There are some good adverseries coming up to take the throne though. But then again it's been 4 years. Time for the legend to finally step down and rest.

Evidence speaks for itself. This is by far, hands down, my favourite racing game. Much much better than Need for Speed series.

Oh and don't hesitate to buy the game just because the studio is closed. The servers are still up and running. There is a ton of players still roaming around. It's fun.

reviewText:
One hell of a great game.

(EDITED 17/06/2015)
The first TDU was a great game and the second one has pushed it a little further.  You get the original island of TDU and the new island, so 2 massive islands to drive around.

The bikes have been added as a DLC and there is not much to choose from to make it a real selection.

Great thing about the game is that you can drive the original map AND the new map with the game, so it is two huge maps in one game.  I mean huge!

The graphics are nicely done, the car detail is nice inside and out and with the casino the game adds a great community feature. I have friends who only play the casino which is good.

When you done the entire game 100% which will take you some serious hours because it is some serious driving, and if you like driving games with exploring on long roads with nice scenery then this is the game for you.

I 100% the game in some hours, and then spent a massive chunk of time cruising around with friends which is top fun.

I literally have no problems with this game, I enjoy everything about it.

I hope they release a TDU3.  If you enjoy driving games with open world, then you will enjoy this game, and added with friends, makes it even better.  Cruise with some beautiful cars in some really nice scenery.

One sad thing about the game is that there is not that many people online anymore, really the community is what made the game amazing and now it is extremely quiet I find.
There used to be hundreds online playing in the casino, poker matches and so much more... Now it's all dead to me (At the time of writing this review)

reviewText:
Tho it is not the greatest, for 20bucks or less, it is worth the price if you enjoy an open world racing game. Just don't expect a lot of variation in the terrain as both Ibiza and Oahu are mostly jungle and urban roads.

The game provides a LOT of road, but as with many racing games, you have to unlock everything by leveling up certain in game attributes. It can feel like a chore at times, but there is a lot of racing to be had (plus crafting your own races too).

On the whole, it takes some getting used to, but TDU2 is a fun game if you are just looking to get in a car and drive.

reviewText:
After abou 100 hours into the game it does prove to be a decent game at it's core, despite it's shortcomgs their is allot to explore and to experience. perhaps in the long run a bit repatative.

The good: Two Islands to Explore, Ibiza and Hawaii. Ibiza is a nice starting area with plenty roads and off road experiences. Hawaii is were it gets more interesting allot more roads and slopes to experience same goes for offroading
Excellent fun to Trash in certain routes especially with a friend driving around.

Driving experience is very challenging, in a very positive way you can spend hours trial and error certain races/time trials.
Sometimes it does get a bit tedious.
And in a negative way you discover a strange performance optimization, where to un-explained reasons you flip/tumble/roll or other. Even when there is no reason for every now and then the car spins at low speeds in certain hard corners (Like a front wheel locks even modern cars which have ABS now a days this shouldn't be happening) It doesn't happen that much. But watch out for gaps/jumps and what not you need to moderate your speeds here.

Haven't noticed it on Ibiza much (So not sure) but there are some mountain roads on Hawaii that haven't been finisched sadly lots of potentiol but very bumpy, instead of smooth driving. Not many just a few roads are like that and you'll have to find them to experience why.

Also to do advanced racing tournaments/cups you have to attain licenses all though a great idea, it leaves no margins for error in the sense you have no experience how the car handles and drive blindly the license objectives which are a bit annoying  doable but feels a bit useless. For future iterations these things need to be updated/modernized or something new.

Regardless of all the negative points for me Personally The Driving experience does outweigh the negative aspects of the game. I truly enjoy touring around the islands and trying to find new fun twisties to master.

Online experience besides driving with a couple of friends haven't really tried the Challenges in a big degree yet also there are allot of players that use mods and what not some with good intentions and others with bad.

In the end to do everything is this game is a challenge and also a time sink to get the full experience.
I'm a gamer that usually play's allot of genre's with a few exceptions.

reviewText: I remember seeing ads for Test Drive Unlimited 2 back before it was released and being absolutely floored with the freedom and graphical fidelity promised. Several years later I had all but forgotten it’s existence when suddenly it popped up in the steam winter sale. What perfect timing! I was itching for a good open world driving game and along comes one that I had wanted so badly on sale for just a few bucks.\nWell 10 hours later my itch is gone, but TDU2 makes a terrible scratcher. I’m not sure if I would have been as disappointed had I picked up the game in its prime, but with the multiplayer non-existent and the game itself being an absolute nightmare to install and get running due to the servers being neglected for the past 3 or 4 years, there is little left to be loved about this game. It’s really cool to see all the car brands licensed and buying houses to decorate definitely appeals to the Sims lover in me, but finding the dealers is a pain and the game world is unfathomably massive. It’s fun to drive and the cars handle well, but the amount of mundane driving about you end up doing causes your eyes to glaze over. By the 8th or 9th hour of play I found myself watching Netflix while I systematically scour a city for a particular dealer or make my way across the world to a different race. At that point I realized it just wasn't that fun and I uninstalled it.

reviewText:
It might be fun for single player, but this game is pretty much dead unless you have a dedicated friend or group of friends to play with. If you don't, keep in mind that this game is pretty much single player.

The good:
Cruising, open world, racing, lots of cars, lots of roads, customization of avatar and car, basic tuning of cars, houses, the old tdu 1 map, the new map, offroad vehicles, motorcycles are back, and day/night & weather cycling, random encounters with some online people will result in a nice group cruise or legit race.

The bad:
Mainly a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ contest between most people even in open world cruising, massive amounts of cheating, cheating, more cheats, cheaters trying to impress others by cheating, cheaters trying to annoy others by cheating, dated graphics, limited tuning options (especially gear ratios), limited suspension and grip preferences for off road vehicles, and a bunch of dlc that is not worth it.

I boot this game up for a casual experience and don't plan on taking it too seriously. I still find myself having fun with it doing my own thing and meeting good people while blocking or un-linking from the dips that have issues they need to sort out on their own time. Knowing this, I can't recommend this game to anyone that wants to race online, have a fun experience with all the dynamics of this game, or play this game as it was originally intended.

Also, all the leader boards are jacked up. Top scores dominated by cheaters soon after the game was released. There are plenty of other solid games out there for racing/cruising/tuning.


A typical experience for many:

Run into a stop sign: no problem. Run into a tiny bush with flowers on it: brick wall. Decide you want to get off the road and cruise the HUGE open terrain? Sweet. Find out how difficult it is to navigate around most terrain with all the obstacles". Finally find a nice open space to floor it. See tall wheat fields and want to frolic through them;-- stopped by a tiny wooden fence hidden in the wheat. Turn around and go back into the wilderness and punch it. Yay; car stopped dead in it's tracks by a boulder hidden by a one foot tall patch of grass. Give up and go back onto the road to giv'r. Floor it. About to hit top speed; a car spawns out of nowhere 15 ft in front of you. Decide to just cruise; a random player online decides to turn on tank mod and harass you a bit or show you how fast he/she can go and get you to ride coop to be amazed. reviewText:
One of the best driving games you will ever play.

This game is a mixed bag. As far as single player goes; it's a great driving game if you like time trials or just relaxing cross country driving. Singleplayer races aren't very difficult because the ai is pretty easy but a lot of the time trials and other solo challenges are fairly fun and some will require some practice. Singleplayer isn't too special, though. It's not bad but the game was clearly designed with multiplayer as the main focus.

Because as for the multiplayer.. You're given the choice to either play online or offline when creating and in-game profile. If you choose to play online then you'll seemlessly see other players driving around the island that you can use voice or text chat with. Challenging other players is encouraged since you get rank points for doing things such as adding people to your friend list or doing challenges with others. There's also ai police that drive around which will get upset if you act malicious towards other drivers. Being too much of a bully will put you into a police chase and if any other players are nearby, they'll be given the choice of getting a police car and being sent after you. The fun of this feature is partially off-set by how most players drive Bugatti's and other supercars making them hard to catch but it's still a nice tough. You can also bet money against others in these challenges which adds a little more purpose.

One of the best parts of the game that shines is the world compared to other driving/racing games. You're given two detailed recreations of both Ibiza and Oahu. In a lot of cases you can actually use a real map to help navigate both of the islands. There's all sorts of roads and highways and rural trails that you can drive on, and if you really want to you can just drive off the road completely. There's no invisible walls keeping you from driving off the road and nearly every mountain has a way to the top if your car can handle the slopes (and there are cars specifically meant for offroading.)
To top of the world's detail.. You can go into various shops and buy clothes or haircuts or cosmetic surgery. You can walk into dealer ships to look at cars in detail and buy them and you can even buy houses and apartments. If you're playing online, you'll also see other players walking around in the public areas, otherwise you can invite them into your home for shenanigans. Here in 2015, it's no GTA Online but it's still wonderful if you're looking for a more relaxed environment where someone won't try to blow you up every few minutes. Also the soundtrack is pretty chill and varied.

With that said, it's pretty much a recreational driving MMO with no monthly subscription and a cash shop that only consists of a few completely optional cars that only cost around a dollar each to unlock (the DLC only unlocks them; you still have to pay for them with ingame money so it still retains a degree of balance.) The only DLC that's mandatory for certain features is the Casino DLC which lets you gamble and win a Casino-exlusive car, and the motorcycle DLC. But seeing as DLC is very cheap, it's not too big of a deal.

Tl;dr buy it if you wanna kill time with cars and endless roads. You get a ton of that pricetag of $20..
Though, keep in mind that some people have a hard time setting up the mandatory account with Atari.
Once you get past that, you're in for a good time.

reviewText:
If we put aside the fact that the game *used to* be very annoying and buggy, and rarely started up, this is my honest review:

TDU2 is a fun, active racing/free roam game that's great for everybody. WIth a lot of missons, many ways to earn money, and the ability to cruise in your favourite car - it sure is a game worth putting time into, and has a lot of replayability too.

Personally, I love this game. I bought it for my PS3 because I heard it was buggy for the PC (at the time) - but now that it's not too buggy, and you can actually start the game up, it's a great game that I don't regret paying the full price (£14.99 currently) for... at all.

Honestly, if you love your cars/autos like me, get it. You won't regret it.

Overall, good job Atari! (No, you didn't read that wrong)

reviewText: Test Drive Unlimited 2 is what you would call a blatant console port, in other words a total insult to pc gamers. The kb+mouse combo just feels awkward while playing TDU2. The game also runs like ♥♥♥♥ even on high end machines; I have a 6 core AMD clocked to 3.4 GHz combined with an ATI 5850 OC edition yet I still have visible graphical lag in this game. Furthermore this is not a racing game, yes you can drive cars around, but the racing aspect in this game is just half baked. TDU2 is Eden Games attempt at emulating face-book in a pseudo-racing genre. The sad part is that your avatar/house is more customizable than your car. This games physics engine also appears to be absent. You can ram in to trucks all day, the only visible damage you will have on your car is dirt and a couple scratches. There are many more problems but I am on a 180 char limit. Just know that if you buy this game, expect to be blown away by mediocrity.

reviewText:
As a fan of Test Drive Unlimited 1 on XBOX 360 I was put off with all the reviews I have read when it came out so much in fact I forgot about the game until a friend of mine mentioned it during the Winter Sale 2014, He paid for himself and me a copy about £3.49 I think it was and oh boy how Atari just rushed this out and tried to get as much coin in before they went bust or to whatever state there in now. The game is terrible from the very first game car handling is out the window and is just stiff and arcady, vehicle sounds are awful mostly to me seem re used for every car but higher pitched for high end cars, the island looks ok not upgraded in visuals over TD1 as I would of thought.

The story is awful your car parker guy who starts off dreaming he's been giving a Ferrari which turns out the woman who gives you it it nothing but the real owner of the car???, who then thinks she is punishing you by driving her to her destination because she's going to be late okkkkkkkkkkkk. The voice acting is terrible really poor like they just used the own devs creating the game to give the samples to save money, your player while driving the car is as stiff as a bloke getting a rectal exam it's beyond a joke.

But it's the installation of the game thats a right royal pain in the backside for anyone installing it now it still has secuROM whch to me is pointless considering Atari really ain't around anymore and sometimes the online are up or down. With this game registering through STEAM why bother with SecuROM what's the point really I will be always baffled as to why games carry such things when you need to be signed into STEAM for most games they could of just gave it an always online system. In todays games we mostly are always online for multiplayer but I don't think a game like this really needs SecuROM, it took me about 30 mins to understand what to do to activate the dam game basically you copy and paste the CD KEY into the box provided to activate it and your LIMITED to 4 yes 4 ACTIVATIONS which you can earn back when you remove it but again this system is just pointless.

reviewText:
This is a great first game from this hit new indie developer 'Atari'. Stunning graphics, they deserve all the backing for this game so you should definitely buy it to support them; after all  that's how indie games work right? A few bugs that these guys could change like when you reverse, but when a game is made in some nerd's garage what do you expect, you dig? The gameplay overall is quite good, however going online is not so good because you have to make an online account and can't switch an offline account to online, but when a game is made in some nerd's garage what do you expect, you dig? Personally the lack of many  classic cars is a downer for me, but when a game is made in some nerd's garage what do you expect, you dig? These indies really know how to make a game and would recommend any day. 9/10, would certainly Cormier again. The last thing I want to get to is the crashing. It sometimes crashed when using the map to teleport from place to place, but when a game is made in some nerd's garage what do you expect, you dig? That should bring us to the end of my review, thanks. Not much choice of rims is another problem I found with this game, but when a game is made in some nerd's garage what do you expect, you dig? A problem I probably should have mentioned earlier as it's quite big, is that there is a fatal lack of jumping ability when acting as the avatar, but when a game is made in some nerd's garage what do you expect, you dig? Among other problems there arises a few that are also rather grand and should definitely be seen to by this indie developer when he/she has the time. One of these is the fact that all the male characters when starting off look rather camp and are thin; standards that I think nobody should have to try to meet. This also goes for the women in the game, as they are portrayed very sexually at times, especially when washing one's car, and I think that this kind of material should not be viewed by anyone under the age of 13, but when a game is made in some nerd's garage what do you expect, you dig? However, my respect goes out to this indie developer who did take the liberty to include an option to make your character of a different ethnicity; my personal choice is black. Another problem I found when playing this game is the fact that the in game birds will not seem to land on my yacht, but when a game is made in some nerd's garage what do you expect, you dig? One problem I encountered much to my dismay, was that there are no Ferrari tuners! Picture this, I drive out of the virtual showroom with my shiny new Ferrari, just to find out that I can't tune it to be the best it can be! But when a game is made in some nerd's garage what do you expect, you dig? Here is a list of cars I wish they would include in this game, and hopefully it will be seen by indie developer 'Atari' so that he/she can add them:
> Lamborghini Miura
> Mazda 3
> Ford GT
> Dodge Viper
> The Ford Escort from Fast and Furious 6
> Supermarine Spitfire MK26b

The final thing I want to address is the lack of all and any pimp shops. The sort that people go to to get sick new gold and blue rims, a green pearl paintjob, lower their suspension dramatically, and increase their overall pimpiality, but when a game is made in some nerd's garage what do you expect, you dig? Also can you add sandwiches please because I think my avatar is hungry.

reviewText: Wow I don't even know where to start with this game. I've finished it twice on the ps3 and 5 times on the pc. Hawaii which is soooooo big and lets you explore just so much. It's honestly an incredible game. I honestly get this game isn't up to par with recent games but for 2011 damn dude. This is amazing. This is a game made to last. Sadly no tdu3 but this is enough. Again amazing game definately would pay 100$ for it.

reviewText:
Данная игра я считаю очень интересна!
так как в ней есть много игровых функций которые подошли бы почти каждому игроку !
в общем плюсы игры:
+ в игре есть огромный мир в котором можно попасть куда душа пожелает (в мерах разумного конечно).
+в игре присутствует какой-то сюжет и играть более чем интересней.
+атмосфера игры просто великолепна, особенно в дождь хочется включить режим от 1-го лица и сидеть наблюдать как капают капли дождя на машину .
+большой выбор машин разного вида, от легковой до багги , но и есть там ещё 3 мотоцикла но они за реальные деньги .
+ выбор и изменение персонажа под свой стиль и вкус.
+мультиплеер , конечно играть в сингле порой интересно но когда играешь с другом игра превращается в сущий ад веселья.
Но и конечно как и в другой любой игре будут присутствовать минусы!
минусы:
-в игре плохо проработана физика поведения машин (мото) в воздухе они как будто падают как бревно.
-не понятные заносы при старте машины .
